Situation1: They notice a mentee struggling with time management during casual check-ins.
Expectation2: Attend weekly church services to worship and participate in community activities
Situation2: They think about joining Sunday worship when time allows
Story:
I sat across from Jamie, my mentee, as she nervously tapped her pen against her notebook. She confessed she was overwhelmed, her deadlines piling up, her weekends swallowed by work. As her mentor, I felt the urge to guide her, to help her carve out time for herself, to encourage her to set boundaries and prioritize her well-being. I wanted to model balance, to show her that growth meant more than just professional achievements.

But as I listened, my mind drifted to the church bells I hadn’t heard in weeks. Sunday worship was a cornerstone of my faith, a time to reconnect with God and my community. Yet, lately, I’d been telling myself I’d go “when time allows,” always finding reasons to skip. Now, as I urged Jamie to make time for what mattered, I felt a pang of guilt. How could I encourage her to prioritize her values when I was neglecting my own? The expectations of being a supportive mentor and a committed Christian pressed in on me, each demanding more than I seemed able to give. I sat in silence, wrestling with the advice I wanted to give and the example I was actually setting.
